Issues.Title: Signal Froms wrong attribute on disable()
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

When using Signal Forms, and the form control gets disabled, instead of adding the "disabled" attribute to the element, it adds the "disable" attribute.

form configuration:

  myForm =form<MyClass>(this.myModel, path=>{
    disabled(path.rating, ()=> this.state.disabled());
    disabled(path.myName, ()=> this.state.disabled());
  });

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
This is the element shown in the dom when state.disabled() is true. When false, of course, then "disable" attribute dissapears.

<input type="text" name="ng.form6.myName" disable="">
```

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI       : 21.0.0-next.7
Angular           : 21.0.0-next.7
Node.js           : 22.17.1
Package Manager   : npm 10.9.2
Operating System  : win32 x64

Issues.Body:

Previously, Angular.io included a section for fallback configuration examples https://v17.angular.io/guide/deployment#fallback-configuration-examples.

This section no longer appears on Angular.dev: https://angular.dev/tools/cli/deployment#server-configuration

Issues.Title: fix(core): control not recognized when input has directive injecting ViewContainerRef
Issues.Body:
When a directive injects a `ViewContainerRef`, the runtime inserts a container that was throwing off the logic that recognizes native controls.

These changes switch to check if the node is a native control through the `TNode`. This also makes it a bit less prone to breaking during SSR.

Fixes #64362.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(core): control not recognized when input has directive injecting ViewContainerRef" (#64368)

Issues.Title: incorrect syntax highlighting for @for blocks using triple curly braces
Issues.Body: ### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? language-service ### Is this a regression? No ### Description The Angular language service highlights the template as invalid when using the `@for` block with triple curly braces (`{{{ }}}`), even though the code compiles and runs correctly. The {{{ item.value }}} syntax works fine at runtime (valid Angular template syntax for `@for`), but VS Code highlights the last } as a syntax error. Example ```ts @Component({ selector: 'app-root', template: `@for (item of items; track item.value) {{{ item.value }}}`, }) export class App { items = [{ value: '1' }, { value: '2' }, { value: '3' }]; } ``` I think this might be related to the Angular Language Service or possibly just a VS Code issue. If it turns out to be the latter, please feel free to close this issue. ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug _No response_ ### Please provide the exception or error you saw ```true ``` ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular 21.0.0-next.6 ``` ### Anything else? _No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "incorrect syntax highlighting for @for blocks using triple curly braces" (#64364)

Issues.Title: ERROR RuntimeError: NG0318: '<input>' is an invalid control host. The host must be a native form control (such as <input>', '<select>', or '<textarea>') or a custom form control component with a 'value' or 'checked' model.
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Upgrading from `21.0.0-next.5` to `21.0.0-next.6` results in runtime errors when using signal forms. Previously working forms are throwing the following error:

```bash
ERROR RuntimeError: NG0318: '<input>' is an invalid control host. The host must be a native form control (such as <input>', '<select>', or '<textarea>') or a custom form control component with a 'value' or 'checked' model.
```

Either the implementation or the error message contains a mistake, because input is a native form control.

The form looks as follows:

```html
<form novalidate>
	<input [control]="customerForm.firstName" />
</form>

```

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/timdeschryver/Sandbox/pull/53

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
ERROR RuntimeError: NG0318: '<input>' is an invalid control host. The host must be a native form control (such as <input>', '<select>', or '<textarea>') or a custom form control component with a 'value' or 'checked' model.
```

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI       : 21.0.0-next.7
Angular           : 21.0.0-next.7
Node.js           : 22.16.0
Package Manager   : pnpm 10.18.1
Operating System  : win32 x64

┌───────────────────────────┬───────────────────┬───────────────────┐
│ Package                   │ Installed Version │ Requested Version │
├───────────────────────────┼───────────────────┼───────────────────┤
│ @angular/build            │ 21.0.0-next.6     │ 21.0.0-next.6     │
│ @angular/cli              │ 21.0.0-next.7     │ 21.0.0-next.7     │
│ @angular/common           │ 21.0.0-next.7     │ ^21.0.0-next.6    │
│ @angular/compiler         │ 21.0.0-next.7     │ ^21.0.0-next.6    │
│ @angular/compiler-cli     │ 21.0.0-next.7     │ 21.0.0-next.7     │
│ @angular/core             │ 21.0.0-next.7     │ ^21.0.0-next.6    │
│ @angular/forms            │ 21.0.0-next.7     │ ^21.0.0-next.6    │
│ @angular/platform-browser │ 21.0.0-next.7     │ ^21.0.0-next.6    │

## What is the new behavior?

Fixes https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/45033

This PR enhances Angular's extended diagnostics by adding documentation links to error messages, improving the developer experience when encountering template errors.

Benefits
- Faster Problem Resolution: Developers can immediately access detailed explanations and examples

- Self-Documenting Errors: Reduces the need to search external documentation

- Consistent Experience: All extended diagnostics now provide uniform help resources

- Educational Value: Helps developers understand Angular best practices

Impact
- No breaking changes: Only enhances error messages

- No performance impact: Changes are compile-time only

- Improved DX: Better onboarding for developers learning Angular templates

Testing
- Verified that diagnostic messages display correctly with new links

- Confirmed that existing error examples and formatting are preserved

- Ensured links point to valid Angular documentation URLs

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

Issues.Title: docs: add missing code formatting around `@defer` in templates/defer guide
Issues.Body: ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/contributing-docs/commit-message-guidelines.md - [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [ ] Bugfix - [ ] Feature - [x] Code style update (formatting, local variables) - [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes) - [ ] Build related changes - [ ] CI related changes - [x] Documentation content changes - [ ] angular.dev application / infrastructure changes - [ ] Other... Please describe: ## What is the current behavior? https://angular.dev/guide/templates/defer In the **Deferred Loading (`@defer`)** documentation, the directive name `@defer` is missing code-style backticks in this sentence: > By default, a @defer block is triggered when the browser state becomes [idle](/guide/templates/defer#idle). ## What is the new behavior? Adds the missing backticks around `@defer` for consistency with Angular documentation style: > By default, a `@defer` block is triggered when the browser state becomes [idle](/guide/templates/defer#idle). This improves readability and matches the formatting used for other directives (e.g., `*ngIf`, `@for`, `@switch`). ## Does this PR introduce a breaking change? - [ ] Yes - [x] No ## Other information N/A
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs: add missing code formatting around `@defer` in templates/defer guide" (#64357)

The “Build environments / Configuring application environments” page on angular.dev describes how to manage environment-specific configuration via environment.ts replacements.

Issues.Title: Allow defining application providers in `bootstrapModule`
Issues.Body:
This commit adds `applicationProviders` to the `bootstrapModule` options
object. This allows specifying additional providers at the location of
bootstrap, which makes default providers much easier to accomplish.

Using this, we can refine the approach taken for downgrade_module to use
this more direct API rather than the additional provider variable dance.

(first commit is in a separate PR and is effectively rolled back by the second)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Allow defining application providers in `bootstrapModule`" (#64354)

Issues.Title: perf(forms): optimize `[field]` binding instructions
Issues.Body:
Caches information about the kind of form control that a `TNode` represents in `TNodeFlags`. This avoids redundant computations on subsequent template create and update passes.

Renames the `INVALID_CONTROL_HOST` error code to
`INVALID_FIELD_DIRECTIVE_HOST` for clarity and adds a test for it.

Issues.Title: refactor(core): fix ZoneJS-by-default providers for async downgradeMo…
Issues.Body:
…dule

This fixes the code to retain ZoneJS by default in the providers for downgradeModule when the `bootstrapModule` is used. Prior to this change, the async `bootstrapModule`/`compileNgModuleFactory` could be called multiple times through `downgradeModule` before `bootstrapModuleFactory` got called and used the zone providers.

Note: marked refactor since this only applies to the -next release and we shouldn't have this change in the changelog as a fix.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/build): support `.test.ts` files by default in unit test builder
Issues.Body:
The unit test discovery logic previously had hardcoded conventions for `.spec.ts` files. This made it inflexible for projects that use other common patterns, such as `.test.ts`.

This change introduces support for `.test.ts` files by default and refactors the discovery logic to be more flexible and maintainable.

Key changes:
- The `unit-test` builder schema now includes both `**/*.spec.ts` and `**/*.test.ts` in its default `include` globs.
- The internal test discovery logic in `test-discovery.ts` is refactored to use a configurable array of test file infixes (`.spec`, `.test`).
- This allows the smart-handling of static paths (e.g., `ng test --include src/app/app.component.ts`) to correctly resolve the corresponding test file for both conventions.
- JSDoc comments and variable names have been updated to improve clarity and reflect the new, more flexible approach.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular/build): support `.test.ts` files by default in unit test builder" (#31438)

Issues.Title: Setting CI=true causes Angular 20 builds to fail with exit code -1073740940 on Windows
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler-cli

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

We recently upgraded our application from Angular 19 to 20. When we run a build on our Windows Jenkins server, our angular library fails to build and npm exits with error "-1073740940". When we run local it builds as expected.

I have tracked this down to Jenkins automatically setting the environment variable "CI" to true. I can reproduce the same error by setting the environment variable CI to true. I have yet to see the same error with CI not set or set to false.

I have tried multiple versions of both Node (21.9.5, 22.20.0) and NPM (10.9.3, 11.6.2) and get the same behavior.

_No response_

```true

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): add migration to update `moduleResolution` to `bundler`
Issues.Body:
This commit adds a migration to update the TypeScript `moduleResolution` option to `'bundler'` for improved compatibility with modern package resolution and the new Angular package format.

See: https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#moduleResolution
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@schematics/angular): add migration to update `moduleResolution` to `bundler`" (#31436)

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): introduce initial jasmine-to-vitest unit test refactor schematic
Issues.Body:
This commit introduces the base infrastructure for an experimental jasmine-to-vitest refactoring schematic and the initial set of transformers for lifecycle functions.

The base infrastructure includes the main schematic entry point, the AST transformer driver, and various utilities for AST manipulation, validation, and reporting.

The lifecycle transformers handle:
- fdescribe/fit -> describe.only/it.only
- xdescribe/xit -> describe.skip/it.skip
- pending() -> it.skip()
- Asynchronous tests using the 'done' callback are converted to 'async/await'.

Usage:
`ng generate jasmine-to-vitest [--project <project-name>]`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@schematics/angular): introduce initial jasmine-to-vitest unit test refactor schematic" (#31435)

Issues.Title: build: refactor ng_package substitutions
Issues.Body:
This refactoring moves the substitution for `@angular/ssr` and `beasties` from a global configuration to a local one within the `@angular/ssr` package definition.

This is achieved by introducing an `extra_substitutions` parameter to the `ng_package` function, allowing package-specific substitutions to be defined. This change improves modularity and removes hardcoded paths from the global substitution rules, making the build system cleaner and easier to maintain.

Additionally, this fixes an issue where the generated TypeScript definition files (.d.ts) for `@angular/ssr` had incorrect relative paths for the `beasties` dependency, causing type resolution failures in consuming projects. The new local substitution corrects these paths.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: refactor ng_package substitutions" (#31434)

Issues.Title: ng extract-i18n crashes when consuming a library that uses $localize and has sourceMaps
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? localize ### Is this a regression? Yes ### Description After upgrading to Angular 20, we're seeing `ng extract-i18n` fail. We are consuming components from 3rd party packages created with ng-packagr (same Angular version) and those components use `$localize` in their typescript files. ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug https://github.com/daiscog/angular-20-extract-i18n-issue ### Please provide the exception or error you saw ```true [error] TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'startOfLinePositions') at MessageExtractor.getOriginalLocation (file:///.../node_modules/@angular/localize/tools/bundles/chunk-TZHZOBVD.js:183:41) ... ``` ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular CLI: 20.3.5 Node: 20.19.0 Package Manager: npm 10.8.2 OS: darwin arm64 Angular: 20.3.4 ... common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms, localize ... platform-browser, router Package Version ------------------------------------ @angular-devkit/architect 0.2003.5 @angular-devkit/core 20.3.5 @angular-devkit/schematics 20.3.5 @angular/build 20.3.5 @angular/cli 20.3.5 @schematics/angular 20.3.5 rxjs 7.8.2 typescript 5.9.3 zone.js 0.15.1 ``` ### Anything else? Previously reported in angular/angular#63528, although nothing to do with nx. The minimal example above contains an example 3rd party package (installed from a local .tgz file) which contains the following component: ```ts @Component({ selector: 'lib-foo', template: `

{{foo}}

`, }) export class Foo { readonly foo = $localize`:message@@foo-works:Foo works!`; } ``` This is exported via the main `index.ts` file. The lib was built using `ng-packagr` and `npm pack` ran in the result to create the .tgz file, which is then installed in the example repo. I've monkey-patched `node_modules/@angular/localize/tools/bundles/chunk-TZHZOBVD.js` with the following immediately before the line where the error was thrown: ```js if (!originalSourceFile) { console.log('Looking for ' + originalStart.file); console.log(originalStart.file, location); process.exit(1); } ``` ...and that logs this (paths snipped for brevity): ``` Looking for .../example/libs/foo/src/lib/foo/foo.ts .../example/libs/foo/src/lib/foo/foo.ts { start: { line: 36527, column: 17 }, end: { line: 36527, column: 49 }, file: '.../example/main-D7LCOSUQ.js', text: '`:message@@foo-works:Foo works!`' } ``` Note that there is no such file as `libs/foo/src/lib/foo/foo.ts` in this project - this is actually the relative path to the file in the 3rd party lib project that was packaged with ng-packagr.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ng extract-i18n crashes when consuming a library that uses $localize and has sourceMaps" (#31431)

Issues.Title: @angular/build:unit-test: Launching ng test --include with Windows path fails
Issues.Body:
### Command

test

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

This issue is specific to Windows and launching ng test with a specific file. Vitest is configured as the test runner.

1. Building tests works but running tests fails with the error: "No test files found." if you launch ng test with a Windows path:
```
ng test --browsers Chromium --include "C:\client\src\app\header\header.component.spec.ts"
```

2. Building and running tests work if you launch ng test with a quasi-POSIX path on Windows:
```
ng test --browsers Chromium --include "C:/client/src/app/header/header.component.spec.ts"
```

3. Building tests fails if you launch ng test with a full POSIX path on Windows:
```
ng test --browsers Chromium --include "/c/client/src/app/header/header.component.spec.ts"
```

Since the native Windows path is not working, you can't use ${file} in launch.json of Visual Studio Code. Similarly, the full POSIX path ${command:extension.commandvariable.file.filePosix}" is not working either. This prevents the launching of the current test file on Windows.


### Minimal Reproduction

Reproduced with 21.0.0-next.7

Issues.Title: build: improve source map configuration for better debugging
Issues.Body:
This commit refactors the jasmine_test rule in tools/defaults.bzl to use the centralized version from @devinfra//bazel/jasmine:jasmine.bzl. This simplifies the rule by removing manual source-map-support handling.

Source map generation has been standardized across the project by enabling the sourceMap option in the root tsconfig.json and removing conflicting inline source map settings from test-specific configurations.

These changes significantly improve the developer experience by enabling breakpoints to be set directly within TypeScript source files when debugging tests in editors like VSCode.

Issues.Title: [reopen] ng serve does not recognize "Accept: */*" header and returns a 404 for requests with route fragments
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Currently playwright sends `Accept: */*` header, and receive 404 error. I reopened #12613, since it is still relevant.

### Minimal Reproduction

Run playwright test, that loading angular dev server page.

```typescript
it('test', async ({page}) => {
  await page.goTo('http://localhost:4200');
});
```

### Exception or Error

```text

```

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>GoogleChrome/lighthouse (lighthouse)</summary>

### [`v13.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/blob/HEAD/changelog.md#1300-2025-10-10)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/compare/v12.8.2...v13.0.0)

[Full Changelog](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/compare/v12.8.2...v13.0.0)

We expect this release to ship in the DevTools of [Chrome 143](https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/schedule), and to PageSpeed Insights within a week.

#### New contributors

Thanks to our new contributors 👽🐷🐰🐯🐻!

- Benjamin R Gibson [@​brgibson](https://redirect.github.com/brgibson)
- Leonardo Poletto [@​leopoletto](https://redirect.github.com/leopoletto)

#### Notable Changes

- performance: remove audits replaced by [performance insights](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/moving-lighthouse-to-insights) ([#​16729](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16729))
- remove preload-fonts, uses-rel-preload audits ([#​16716](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16716))
- remove font-size audit ([#​16701](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16701))
- remove offscreen-images audit ([#​16748](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16748))
- remove no-document-write audit ([#​16750](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16750))
- remove uses-passive-event-listeners audit ([#​16751](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16751))
- remove third-party-facades audit ([#​16710](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16710))

#### Core

- remove ResponseCompression artifact ([#​16755](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16755))
- remove OptimizedImages artifact ([#​16754](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16754))
- remove DOMStats artifact ([#​16753](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16753))
- remove CacheContents artifact ([#​16752](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16752))
- remove empty first-meaningful-paint audit ([#​16749](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16749))
- remove some unused computed artifacts ([#​16735](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16735))
- defer to trace engine for lcp-breakdown, ttfb ([#​16733](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16733))
- error on unknown category in onlyCategories ([#​16720](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16720))
- drop compat traces / devtoolsLogs artifacts ([#​16708](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16708))
- import json as modules ([#​16700](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16700))
- anchor-elements: don't consider ancestorListeners ([#​16731](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16731))
- dom-size-insight: add numericValue ([#​16741](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16741))
- emulation: always match host browser's version milestone ([#​16677](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16677))
- font-display-insight: disable entity sum for est. savings ([#​16746](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16746))
- image-delivery-insight: add node item for image ([#​16714](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16714))
- inspector-issues: remove empty arrays ([#​16736](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16736))
- legacy-javascript: update caniuse data ([#​16699](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16699))
- network-request: remove receiveHeadersStart M115 compat ([#​16738](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16738))
- scoring: adjust a11y weights and document approach ([#​16624](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16624))
- server-response-time: defer to Document Latency insight ([#​16715](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16715))
- trace-elements: remove unused event types ([#​16734](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16734))
- trace-elements: handle shadow roots ([#​16718](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16718))

#### CLI

- improve description for `form-factor` flag ([#​16682](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16682))

#### Report

- add adornment to audit description when not scored ([#​13014](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/13014))

#### Deps

- upgrade deps ([#​16760](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16760))
- remove parse-cache-control ([#​16747](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16747))
- upgrade trace\_engine to 0.0.61 ([#​16745](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16745))
- upgrade [@​esbuild-kit/esm-loader](https://redirect.github.com/esbuild-kit/esm-loader) to 2.6.5 ([#​16730](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16730))
- upgrade deps ([#​16724](https://redirect.github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/pull/16724))

Issues.Title: feat(CdkConnectedOverlay): Expose current position
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

`CdkConnectedOverlay`'s positioning is controlled through `@Input('cdkConnectedOverlayPositions') positions: ConnectedPosition[]`. But, there is no way to know which `ConnectedPosition` is currently applied.

I propose to create a new public parameter in class  `CdkConnectedOverlay` named `currentPosition`, preferably a `signal` which will return the current `ConnectedPosition` which is applied to `CdkConnectedOverlay`

### Use Case

Having access to current `ConnectedPosition` will allow users to

1. Style the panels effectively, like showing an arrow pointing towards it's trigger
2. Animate panels effectively, like using `translate` CSS properties
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(CdkConnectedOverlay): Expose current position" (#32059)

Issues.Title: feat(cdkDrag): Restrict drag movement by individual boundary sides (top, right, bottom, left)
Issues.Body: ### Feature Description **Description:** Introduce a configuration option for `cdkDrag` that allows developers to restrict dragging beyond specific sides of a boundary container. This would enable more nuanced control than the current `cdkDragBoundary`, which enforces containment uniformly on all sides. **Proposed API (example):** ### Use Case **1. MatDialog Handle Visibility Constraint** Enable users to drag a MatDialog freely within a grid layout, but restrict movement beyond the top and left/right edges of the viewport to ensure the dialog’s drag handle remains visible and accessible. This prevents scenarios where users accidentally drag the dialog off-screen, making it difficult or impossible to reposition without refreshing the page or resetting the layout. - Preserves usability by keeping the drag handle within reach. - Prevents frustration from dialogs becoming “lost” off-screen. - Supports responsive design by adapting to dynamic viewport sizes. **2. Dashboard Layout Editors** Allow users to drag widgets freely within a grid but prevent them from overlapping fixed headers or sidebars. For example: - Restrict dragging above the top edge to preserve a sticky toolbar. - Allow overflow on the bottom for expandable panels. **3. Mobile UI Builders** In mobile layout editors, you might want to: - Prevent dragging past the left/right edges to maintain responsive design. - Allow vertical overflow for scrollable content zones. **4. Game Interfaces** In drag-based puzzle or strategy games: - Restrict dragging outside the playfield on specific sides (e.g., prevent dragging off the top to simulate gravity). - Allow dragging into inventory zones only from certain directions. **5. Design Tools (e.g., Canva-style editors)** Enable asymmetric drag zones: - Prevent dragging elements off the canvas on the left and top (to preserve alignment). - Allow overflow on the right for snapping to guides or external panels. **6. Workflow Builders / Flowchart Editors** When building visual workflows: - Restrict dragging nodes above the top boundary to avoid overlapping with global controls. - Allow dragging below for expanding the flow. **7. Accessibility-Driven Interfaces** For users with motor impairments: - Restrict dragging to safe zones to prevent accidental loss of visibility. - Customize side restrictions based on user preferences or device orientation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(cdkDrag): Restrict drag movement by individual boundary sides (top, right, bottom, left)" (#32044)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(all): Improvement suggestion: style docs to emphasize integrity of each method
Issues.Body: ### Documentation Feedback Hi Angular Material Team! This is a suggestion to improve the styling of your generated documentation -- particularly the "API" pages. Something I've noticed over the years is that the API pages are a bit hard to read. In particular, the styling of those pages make it difficult to identify individual methods, and to understand which information to associate with which method. (Context: I just spent a fair amount of time debugging something related to `flexibleDimensions` on the CDKOverlay, and better/more easily intelligible docs would have definitely helped.) My suggestion is to make simple tweaks to your styles that emphasize the boundaries between relevant units of functionality (e.g. method, class, etc), rather than using CSS borders to separate the key/label and value/description in bit of documentation about the unit of functionality. Here's an example of what I am talking about -- the first screenshot is the page now, and the second is what happens if you give the table for each method its own background color and border, and remove the inner borders. (3 CSS property change) All of a sudden users can actually distinguish the individual methods, and you can also see that there is no documentation for `detach`. Lots more could be done with spacing, color, and typography, but this is intended as either a quick win/low-hanging fruit suggestion, or more realistically, an issue to add to your evidence pile that the docs could use some redesign with an eye towards information hierarchy in a future release. --- ### Affected documentation page all pages

Issues.Title: Angular Material changes behaviour without a version change
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Angular Material has changed behaviour multiple times without updating its version in the application where it is used (not doing a single `npm install`, using exactly the same version). Specifically, using @angular/material@20.2.7, MatDrawer has changed from not having an animation to having it multiple times:

- Did not have animation at some point before 06/10/2025 (don't remember the exact date, in this case with @angular/material@20.2.5)
- Had an animation at 06/10/2025, 9:50 UTC (with @angular/material@20.2.5 or @angular/material@20.2.7)
- Did not have an animation at 08/10/2025, 11:48 UTC (with @angular/material@20.2.7)
- Did have an animation at 10/10/2025, 12:19 UTC (with @angular/material@20.2.7)

I have also observed these changes in the examples in [https://material.angular.dev/components/sidenav/examples](https://material.angular.dev/components/sidenav/examples), which have suffered the same changes in animations in the same dates, but I cannot assure they have not changed the @angular/material version used.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:

- Create an Angular application that uses MatDrawer, install dependencies just once, and check how the drawer changes from having an animation to not having it in different dates.
- Or check how [https://material.angular.dev/components/sidenav/examples](https://material.angular.dev/components/sidenav/examples) changes from having an animation to not having it in different dates (in some cases without a release).

I know this is not easy to check if nobody else has noticed and it does not happen in the future (that would be fine). But if it happens again in the future, this will help resolve it.


### Expected Behavior

Angular Material changes behaviour only with a version change

### Actual Behavior

Angular Material changes behaviour without a version change

### Environment

- Angular: 20.3.3
- CDK/Material: 20.2.7
- Browser(s): Edge/Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular Material changes behaviour without a version change" (#32051)

- Fixed an issue where `firebase init` would require log in even when no project is selected. ([#​9251](https://redirect.github.com/firebase/firebase-tools/issues/9251))
- Added `remoteconfig:experiments:get`, `remoteconfig:experiments:list`, and `remoteconfig:experiments:delete` commands to manage Remote Config experiments.
- Added `remoteconfig:rollouts:get`, `remoteconfig:rollouts:list`, and `remoteconfig:rollouts:delete` commands to manage Remote Config rollouts.

</details>

Issues.Title: bug(Timepicker): Timepicker issue with FormControl binding
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description When a Timepicker is integrated with a Datepicker and is bound to a formControl instead of property the time does not re-render to display Midnight when the date is changed , as opposed to when it is bound to a property. If the user then saves the record the date saved is at midnight not the displayed time in the Timepicker. ### Reproduction StackBlitz link: Steps to reproduce: 1. [Stackblitz Example Code](https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-rt5ffl8o?file=src%2Fmain.ts) 2. The Stackblitz project will open with 2 Date and Timepickers defaulted to the current date and time. 3. When you change the date using the Datepicker the Timepicker does not re-render to display the updated time of midnight, when it is bound to a formControl. The second Datepicker and Timepicker is bound to a property and does re-render the Timepicker. ### Expected Behavior When the Date is changed using the Datepicker the associated Timepicker shoud re-render to display the updated time to be midnight as when it is bound to a property. ### Actual Behavior The Timepicker remains unchanged when the Datepicker is updated and does not reflect the time of the associated new date selected. ### Environment Angular CLI: 20.0.0 Node: 20.19.1 Package Manager: npm 10.8.2 OS: linux x64 Angular: 20.0.0 ... animations, build, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core ... forms, material, material-date-fns-adapter, platform-browser ... router Package Version ------------------------------------------------------ @angular-devkit/architect 0.2000.0 @angular-devkit/core 20.0.0 @angular-devkit/schematics 20.0.0 @schematics/angular 20.0.0 rxjs 7.8.2 typescript 5.8.2 zone.js 0.15.0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(Timepicker): Timepicker issue with FormControl binding" (#32036)

Issues.Title: Screen reader is not announcing label name for section present under stepper variants in Windows.
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description **User Impact:** Visually impaired users who rely on screen readers will be impacted if Screen reader is not announcing label name for section present under stepper variants in Windows. They won’t know which section they are in, leading to confusion and difficulty completing tasks. ### Reproduction URL: https://material.angular.dev/components/stepper/overview **Steps to reproduce:** 1. Enable NVDA and open the URL: https://material.angular.dev/components/stepper/overview in edge browser. 2. Landing page will get open. 3. Press tab key to reach to the sections present under 'Stepper Variants'. 4. Observe whether screen reader is announcing label name for section present under stepper variants in Windows or not. ### Expected Behavior Screen reader should announce the label name for section present under stepper variants in Windows. ### Actual Behavior Screen reader is not announcing label name for section present under stepper variants in Windows. **Refer Attachment:** Screen reader is not announcing label name for section present under stepper variants in Windows.png Screen reader is not announcing label name for section present under stepper variants in Windows.mp4 https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9e5ee684-4563-444b-8f76-0c69297de5fc ### Environment OS: Windows 11 25H2 (OS Build 26200.6584) Browser: Edge (Version 140.0.3485.94) Angular 20.x. Material: 20.2.7 Screen Reader: NVDA (2025.2), JAWS (2025.2508.120), Narrator URL: https://material.angular.dev/components/stepper/overview
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Screen reader is not announcing label name for section present under stepper variants in Windows." (#32037)
